parts.text: Hello my name is Lynn Loxton and I am going to have a
conversation with Amy rose zero four visible lives

and this is being recorded at the G.C.C. in New York City.
Welcome Amy thank you for agreeing to be interviewed. Look forward to hearing your
story. Thank you.
I have had a disability my whole
life I was born I was called up
but it's kind of sort of affects your vision it just kind of your form of
that you can't see it.
As a child I was diagnosed with dyslexia
But. I'd like to say that
I don't like it when people say oh you have a disability. I
don't want to be viewed as somebody who can't do things in society
. Everybody needs help. It's OK to get
help but I feel like I want to use
my strengths. And
though I know I have businesses that everybody in life has weaknesses nobody's
perfect which I'm glad that I'd like to say
that you know I have my health but I think
that I'm it's very important
just like for instance I have a brother on the West
Coast and.
I am I am trying and hoping that he will
just learn to love me for who I am not teach me
not be my mentor or not lecture me but just learn to
love me and so I wrote a little piece
for The Wanted patients and I'm right and so I'm going to read it
And it's called How I just love your sibling with special needs. If
your sibling who has a brother or sister with special needs just love them. Chances
are they already get enough help so just love and do not try to
lecture or teach them what is said one can do to love
. Their older or younger sibling with special needs. Accept them for who
they are. Do not talk down to them. Do not lecture

. Spend quality time with them go to C.N.N. go on a walk or just for
coffee. How do your siblings. Sometimes that feels nice to be
part of loving your sibling with special needs include encouraging him or her and not
being too critical of everything they do.
Because as a child with special needs what is put down and criticized too much over their
lives. Provide some positive compliments and statements to your sibling
with special needs. Just show them love a nice note or a letter.
Finding out how they are and just to say you love them and are thinking about
them. How I'm used to doing now and then just to ask how are you
. Show some compassion and empathy. Just love your
sibling no teaching or lecturing. Let your sibling with

but be there for them if they need you.
Yes and that's true for anybody who has any kind of
. Disability. That's true for anybody out there
you know chances are that person with special needs gets enough help
so family and friends should just abide by what I read.
And and I really feel like
society looks down to match people with disabilities.
Not all disabilities can be seen.
I hurt my foot five years ago so for
lead it's hard to stand on the bus so I ask for a seat
and sometimes I ask the bus driver for the lift if it's
an older pass and they look at me and they say you don't have
a wheelchair or you don't have practice and I go but
. I'm not good with stairs and I need the lift. And they
say oh but you don't have a wheelchair and I

I always get off on the newer buses in the front of the bus because it's lower down

a few too many stairs for me.
I feel safer about them right now
. At some point that might change
. I'm not sure. And I mean.
I just like to say though that here at the G.C.C.
everyone's accepted for who they are accepted for who I am
in my workplace and also in the building and all the
programs I go to
. It's not Oh do you have a disability you can't work here you have a

And there are programs for people with special needs which are part of

. And it's a good support. It's a very very
good support and I've managed to find my

disabilities are visible and some are not and mine is not visible
. So I think it's important that society be
aware that you know sometimes I'm slow around
stairs sometimes I'm sorry to get off the bus but
I do it. That's the important thing is that I do it and
I just feel like people need to be aware about people with
disabilities and not just realize that
everybody has a full potential in society and
everybody just tries their best
and they shouldn't be denied a job because of a
disability they shouldn't be denied housing
or medical care because of a disability. Everybody has the same rights
. And if this is one thing that comes from this interview that's very
very important. Is it everybody.
We have the same rights and to be given a chance in society at what they want to
do. I'm sure there are doctors out there with disabilities. I'm sure there are surgeons
out there with disabilities. I'm sure there are teachers and
lawyers with disabilities. Society
is a good mix of everyone and we need to keep that in mind
and I hope this is helpful. So
I think I've said my share and I hope I've made a good impression
